Review
Application of common nano-materials for removal of selected metallic species from water and wastewaters: A critical review
Shikha Dubey a, Sushmita Banerjee a, Siddh Nath Upadhyay b, Yogesh Chandra Sharma a,⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi, Varanasi 221005, India b Department of Chemical Engineering & Technology, Indian Institute of Technology (BHU) Varanasi, Varanasi 221005, India

http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2017.05.107 0167-7322/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 29 December 2016 Received in revised form 13 May 2017 Accepted 18 May 2017 Available online 25 May 2017
Wastewater treatment and water purification have always posed challenges to mankind and this problem has become severewith escalating population and industrialization. This topic has attracted the global scientific community. Activated carbon adsorption became popular choice forwater purification but its high cost prompted scientific workers to search for its alternates. In that series, several materials including minerals, waste materials, cellulosic materials, etc. were also applied as adsorbents. Recently, especially after advent of nano technology, there was a shift toward application of nano materials as ‘adsorbents’ and the term was coined as ‘nano adsorbents’. Present reviewhas been focussedon the application of commonnanomaterials for the removal ofmetallic species which are found in aqueous environment. The ‘most common’metallic species are As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Pb, Hg, and Ni. Sb, Pd, Pt, U and Th are the othermiscellaneousmetallic species where nano particles are applied for their removal from aqueous solutions and water. We have critically discussed the articles published recently on this topic.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water pollution is one of the most serious problems posing human health risks and which causes detrimental effect to humanity and other life forms. In recent years the world's rapid economic improvement is gaining momentum and has led to climbing wages, as well as to a fast urbanization and an uncontrolled populace development. Therefore, the planet has experienced an assortment of pressing environmental challenges such as climate change and global warming, extreme era of robust waste, and water pollution, leading to serious environmental degradation and contributes amajor share to the overall imbalance of the ecosystem. It is a well-known that clean water is vital for healthy living. Satisfactory supply of pure and cleandrinkingwater is an essential need for all people on the earth, yet it has been perceived that millions of individuals worldwide are denied of this. Water resources onto every part of the planet are undermined by over abuse and poor administration as well as by environmental pollution. The principle wellspring of water contamination might be ascribed to release of untreated waste, dumping of modern industrial effluents and run-off from rural fields. Moreover, indifferent behaviour of man towards nature and his activity at surface, unintentionally by farming, local effluents, surprisingly by sub-surface or surface disposal of sewage, industrial wastes, and geometrical growth of population has led to adverse effects onwater quality. Unfortunately, due to rapid increase in industrialization, uncontrolled population growth, civilization, rural, and domestic practices, and various other land and ecological progressions, water quality of thewater resources is getting deteriorated continuously. Therefore, in the present situation, water pollution affecting all living creatures, etc. has become a serious issue of global concern for government authorities, academicians, scientists and environmentalists.
Many natural, inorganic and organic constituents have been accounted for as water contaminants. A number of them have serious symptoms and acute toxicities with a couple of them being deadly poisonous and carcinogenic posing threat to the ecosystemof the earth as a whole. The various types of water pollution problems result in the scarcity of water all over the world, in terms of quality and quantity, and pose serious threats to people's well-being. Therefore, providing clean and safe water is a major challenge for the global community [1–3]. As water resource has increasingly become scarce recently, it is evident that theworld is now facing formidable challenges not only inmaintaining good quality ofwater supply, but also in complyingwith the increasingly stringent requirement of environmental legislation for clean drinking water.
As protected and clean water is a nexus vital asset and sustains life on Earth, preserving the aquatic environment and its resources against pollutants is critical to safeguard living organisms. In this regard, mere reliance on conventional solutions is not sufficient, as they are ineffective, time-consuming, and costly. Robust and technological improvements are required for purifying water economically with less chemicals/energy consumption, while addressing environmental impacts in the long term. While the impacts could be minimized using existing treatment techniques, novel and cost-effective technologies are increasingly in demand in the commercial market. As innovations are the only pathways through which long-term improvement could be sustained, new, practical, and local solutions need to be developed not only to overcome barriers to water and sanitation provision, but also to tackle global water pollution problems in sustainable ways. Therefore, new and more advanced approaches are continually being examined to supplement existing traditional water treatmentmethods.
For a couple of decades, distinctive techniques have been produced and utilized for treatment of contaminated water. The most paramount strategies are screening, sedimentation,filtration,micro-and ultrafiltration, centrifugation, crystallization, precipitation, oxidation, floatation, coagulation, solvent extraction, dissipation, refining, reverse osmosis, particle diffusion, electrolysis, electro-dialysis, gravity separation, adsorption, and so on. Adsorption is acknowledged as one of the most
suitable water strategies because of its simplicity of operation and the accessibility of an extensive variety of high adsorption limit and large scale sections [4]. Moreover, adsorption can likewise be utilized for source diminishment and recovery for consumable, mechanical, and other water purposes. Despite these facts, adsorption has specific limits, for example, it couldn't attain a decent status at business levels. Presumably, it is because of the absence of suitable adsorbents of high adsorption capacity and business scale sections. Furthermore, a single adsorbent can't be utilized for various types of pollutants It was observed that, regardless of a few impediments, it will be an exceptional water treatment innovation in the near future.Muchwork has been carried on the abatement of different contaminants fromwater by utilizing adsorption method. Initially, activated carbon [5–8] was utilized for the removal of contaminants from water, which has been supplanted by some low cost adsorbing materials. A number of other adsorbents, e.g. fly ash [9–11], chitosan [12–13], kaolinite [14], zeolite [15–16], montmorillonite [17], sphagnummoss peat [18], wollastonite [19], bentonite [20], sawdust [21], seaweeds [22], soya cake [23], redmud [24] and alumina [25–27] have been incorporated by various workers and reported for the removal of metallic pollutants from aqueous solutions and wastewaters. In the last two decades, nanotechnology has undergone a full-fledged advancement with its requisitions in essentially all branches of science and technology. In this arrangement, water remediation is not denied of nanotechnology.
Nanotechnology is an emerging science with wide applications in the remediation of environmental pollutants. Advances in nano-scale science and engineering are providing unprecedented opportunities to developmore cost effective and environmentally acceptablewater purification processes. In recent years, a great deal of attention has been focused on the synthesis and application of nano-structured materials as adsorbents to remove toxic and harmful compounds from water and wastewater. Resurgence to synthesize and manipulate nano-particles finds use in improvingwater quality in the environment. In perspective of the vitality of water quality and increasing applications of nanotechnology, endeavours have been made to talk about different parts of water remediation by adsorption utilizing nano-adsorbents.
Several reviews have been published so far on the application of nano-materials for water remediation, this work mainly highlights the works that have been carried out during last mostly five years with emphasis on the removal of certain heavy and toxic metals.

sections.heading: 1.1. Adsorption
sections.text:
Adsorption is a mass transfer process which involves the accumulation of substances at the interface of two phases, such as, liquid–liquid, gas–liquid, gas–solid, or liquid–solid interface through the physical forces (physi-sorption) or sometimes through weak chemical forces (chemi-sorption). The adsorption from solution on to a solid occurs as a result of the driving forces of lyophobic character of the solute, relative to the particular solvent, or a high affinity of the solute for the solid. The moleculewhich gets adhered on the solid surface is called the adsorbate and the solid surface is termed as adsorbent. The process of adsorption is influenced by various parameters such as initial metal ion concentration, temperature, nature of adsorbate and adsorbent, pH, contact time, particle size, etc. All adsorption performance processes depend on solidliquid equilibria and on mass transfer rates. The adsorption operation can be batch, semi-batch and continuous. The state of equilibrium is achieved in this vary process when the concentration of pollutant on the solid and in the solution become constant. At this state of equilibrium, the relationship between amount of solid adsorbed and in solution is called an adsorption isotherm. Adsorption isotherms are important for the description of interaction of adsorbate with adsorbent and are critical in optimizing the use of adsorbents. The adsorption is performed for determination of different adsorption parameters. The most common models are Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, Sips, etc. [28–37], which have been tabulated in Table.1. The thermodynamic study is done by ascertaining enthalpy, free energy, entropy, and energy of activation. The adsorption engineering is produced by cluster process accompanied by the segment studies. The improved adsorption technology is applied first at pilot and later on industrial scales.

sections.heading: 1.2. Synthesis of nano-particles
sections.text:
The synthesis of nano-particles is the first and most important step in the process of water treatment through engineered nano-particles. In terms of synthesis of nano-particles, there are two general strategies involved viz., the bottom-up approach (that entails the arrangement of smaller molecules atom-by-atom or molecule-by-molecule into more complex assemblies with the help of certain physical or chemical forces via chemical synthesis, positional assembling, or self-assembling), and the top-down approach (that involves the generation of nano-particles from large size (i.e., granular or micro-scale) materials via mechanical and/or chemical steps includingmilling, etching etc.). There are a number of methods devised for the preparation of nano-particles based on the desiredmorphology, properties, applications etc. which incorporate sol-gel process [38], precipitation [39], co-precipitation [40], catalytic growth [41], mechanical alloying/milling [42], mechano-chemical synthesis [43], impregnation [44], electro-deposition [45], laser ablation [46], inert gas condensation [47], spark discharge generation [48], spray pyrolysis [49], thermal plasma synthesis [50], severe plastic deformation [51], ion sputtering [52],flame synthesis [53], flame spray pyrolysis [54] and laser pyrolysis [55]. The composition and molecular structure of the nano-particles can bemodelled through thesemethods. Among various methods of synthesis of nano-particles proposed so far, sol-gel method, is widely used because it provides fine control overmolecular structure, morphology, pore volume, surface area, density etc. of the materials fabricated for water treatment processes.
Further, based on the size and shapes of the synthesized nano-materials, these can be classified into nano-particles, nano-tubes, nanowires, nano-belts, nano-capsules, nano-fibres, nano-polymers, nanosprings, quantumdots, etc. Each of these nano-materials possess unique properties that are extensively explored.

sections.heading: 1.3. Characterization of nano-particles
sections.text:
The engineered nanoparticles are characterizedwith the help of certain analytical techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier
transform IR (FTIR)spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA), differential thermogravimetric analysis (DTA), triple-point-nitrogen-Brunuaer-EmmettTeller (BET) adsorption etc. and the information altered over through these techniques is summarized in Table 2. Basically, the reported methods are used for the preparation of different types of nano-particles with slight modifications for various applications such as biomedical, biotechnology, materials, electronics, mechanical, optical, environmental sciences, etc. The selection of the technique depends
on the size, properties, starting materials, and the required applications of the nano-particles.

sections.heading: 1.4. Nano-adsorbents
sections.text:
Nano-particles are the engineeredmaterials having at least one of its atomic dimensions in nano (10−9) range. These atomic particles exhibit certainmost striking and fascinating characteristics that enable them to be used in various branches of science and technology including medicines, optics, electronics, environment etc. These engineered nano-particles have a significant amount of surfaces and thus attract much interest to be applied as adsorbents in comparison to macromolecules. These offer the potential for the treatment of contaminated water. The engineered nano-particles have proven themselves as excellent adsorbents due to their unique features. The most important characteristics of these particles which made them ideal adsorbents are small size, catalytic potential, high reactivity, large surface area, ease of separation and large number of active sites for interaction with different contaminants [56–58]. Due to the increasing electronic density at their edges, various functional groups may be attached to the nano-particles to enhance their reactivity, affinity, capacity, and selectivity toward target pollutants in aqueous solutions [59]. So they provide the ability to combine a number of reactive agents together and allow fine control over mass transport properties. These properties are responsible for high adsorption capacities by increasing the surface area, free active valences and surface energies of nano-particles. In light of their high porosity, minor measure, and dynamic surface, nano-adsorbents not just are fit for sequestering contaminants with shifting atomic size, hydrophobicity, and speciation behaviour, additionally empower assembling methodology to devour crude materials productively without discharging its poisonous payload [60]. Nano-adsorbents work quickly, as well as have significant metal-binding capacities. They can be artificially
recovered in the wake of being exhausted. Various nano-particles have been applied in removing radio-nuclides, adsorption of organic dyes, remediation of contaminated water, and magnetic sensing. Metal oxides play a significant role in many fields of nano-technology including nano-catalysis, sensing, super-magnetic properties, and energy storage. Nano size adsorbents have been utilized for themitigation of water pollutants. The commonly used nanoparticles for water treatment are made of akaganeite, alumina, anatase, cadmium sulphide, cobalt ferrite, copper oxide, gold, maghemite, iron, iron oxide, iron hydroxide, nickel oxide, silica, stannous oxide, titanium oxide, zinc oxide, zinc sulphide, zirconia, and some alloys. The various nano-particles synthesized so far for water remediation and their corresponding method of synthesis is tabulated in Table 3. BET surface areas of some magnetic nano-particles most commonly employed in water remediation is depicted in Table 4.

sections.heading: 1.5. Mechanism of the removal of the metallic species by the nanomaterials
sections.text:
The mechanism behind the removal of metallic species by the adsorption process involves three well known steps i.e. film diffusion that entails transport of the adsorbate through a surface film to the exterior of the adsorbent, pore diffusion that assumes diffusion of the adsorbate within the pores of the adsorbent, and intra-particle diffusion includes adsorption of solute at the interior surfaces of the adsorbent (Fig. 1). In order to apprehend the underlying mechanism operative for the adsorption of hazardous metallic species by nanoparticles, the influence of the adsorption processes using different analytical techniques, i.e., infrared (IR) spectroscopy, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) and Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy have been extensively investigated. The purpose of such structural and functional explorations is to provide insight into the probable mechanism responsible for the removal
.
which may involve either one or the combination of the two or more mechanisms such as physical adsorption [176], surface-complexation [177], ion-exchange [136], electrostatic interaction [221] and hard/soft acid-base interaction [307]. The details of adsorption mechanism of themetallic species under study have been presented in their respective sections.

sections.heading: 1.6.1. Mitigation of inorganic pollutants
sections.text:
Being specific to inorganic pollutants some heavy metals are well known water contaminants with high degree of danger and carcinogenicity. Arsenic is regarded as dreadful metal since old time because of its symptoms and lethality. Besides, other metals, for example Mercury (Hg), Lead (Pb), Cadmium (Cd), Chromium (Cr), Selenium (Se), etc. have serious toxicities. At higher dose than reasonable limit, various metals cause detrimental effects on health such as Zinc is needed for the normal development of a person, yet high doses more than the permissible limit of confinement cause poor development and mental fever, Cobalt causes regurgitating, queasiness, asthma, and carcinoma. In addition, cobalt is likewise responsible for thyroid, gastrointestinal, liver problems. Because of such contamination, the surface and groundwaters at a few places of various countries are tainted and not fit for drinking purposes. This scenario stands to compound as the water supply has been polluted by awide assortment of obstinate contaminations from regular alternately mechanical sources.
For removal of heavy metals from water resources through the adsorption process, the most frequently used nano-adsorbents include iron oxides (FeO), silica (SiO2), manganese oxides (MnO2), aluminium oxides (Al2O3), and titanium oxides (TiO2). Iron is known to be one of the most ubiquitous elements on the earth. The widespread availability of resources, and ease in synthesis render nano-sized ferric oxides
(FeOs) to be one of the low-cost adsorbents for toxic metal abatement. Since elemental iron is eco-friendly, nano-FeOs can be directly employed at contaminated sites with negligible risks of secondary contamination [61]. The extensively studied nano-FeOs for heavy metals' removal from water/wastewater include goethite (α-FeOOH) [62], hematite (α-Fe2O3) [63], amorphous hydrous Fe oxides [64], maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) [65–66], magnetite (Fe3O4) [67–72]. Fig. 2 represents the TEM images of some of the nano-FeOs particles commonly used in water treatment through adsorption. The removal of various metallic pollutants onto numerous nano-adsorbents through the process of adsorption has been tabulated in Table 5.
1.6.1.1. Arsenic (As). Arsenic (As) is a metal of particular concern in terms of both human as well as environmental health. In water it is obtained from both natural and anthropogenic sources with weathering and dissolution of arsenic minerals categorized into natural whereas, disposal of solid by-products from combustion processes (e.g., thermal power plants, solid waste incinerators, cement and paper industries), discharge of producedwater from in situ extraction processes (e.g., uranium, oil, and natural gas), and application of arsenic based pesticides [73–74]. Being a relatively sparse but pervasive element, it is of a serious health concern due to its toxicity and carcinogenicity. Long-term exposure to arsenic contaminated water is known to cause pigmentation, neurological disorders, cardio- and cerebro-vascular diseases, thickening (hyperkeratosis), muscular weakness, loss of appetite, nausea, diabetes mellitus, and adverse reproductive outcomes [75–76]. Some other complications, such as Blackfoot disease, as well as cancer in the lungs, bladder, and kidneys are also reported [77–79].
The presence of Arsenic mainly in groundwater is a global problem as its excess in drinkingwater causes a series of humanhealth problems, such as gastrointestinal, skin, liver, and nerve tissue injuries [80]. Global awareness of arsenic contamination of drinkingwater supplies has vault up during the 1990s when N35 million people in Bangladesh andWest Bengal (India) were inadvertently poisoned by drinking arsenic contaminated water [81–82]. Further studies illustrate that elevated levels of naturally occurring arsenic in groundwater are a prevalent problem affectingmany regions of theworld [83]. In order tominimize its health risk, theWorld Health Organization (WHO) set a new guideline limit of 0.01 mg/L in drinkingwater instead of previous 0.05 mg/L limit in 1996 for arsenic which has been adopted by many countries.
Comprehensive efforts are being made [84] and steps have been taken globally to develop effective and affordable technologies for the removal of arsenic from water, but none of them is found effective at
s of adsorption of metal ions by nanoparticles.
the community scale due to unavoidable disadvantages of high cost and associated handling problems.
Adsorption process, being cost-effective and simple in operation, is extensively utilized for abatement of toxic and heavy metals. The scientific efforts of various workers in this area and their findings are discussed here.
Removal of As (V) on 16nano-particles ofmetal oxideswas reported by Hristovski et al. [85], out of which TiO2, Fe2O3, ZrO2, and NiO, were themost important one. All nano-particles were found to be highly efficient with removal capacities of 98% except for ZrO2. The adsorption data followed the Freundlich model for all the nano-particles.
Similarly, activated carbon loaded with nano zero-valent iron was used for the adsorption of arsenic by Zhu et al. [86]. The maximum adsorption capacity was approximately 1.997mg/g in 2.0 mg/L As (III) solution at pH 6.5. The investigation of the effect of the other ions revealed that the presence of phosphate and silicate ions decreased arsenic removal, while the effect of other common ions such as sulfate, carbonate, and oxalate was found to be insignificant. The authors asserted this adsorbent as an ideal one and recommended it for the treatment of arsenic contaminated drinking water.
Further, the group of Zhu et al. [87] synthesized a new adsorbent as activated carbon impregnatedwith nano zerovalent iron, and used it for abatement of arsenate. The adsorption capacitywas found to be approximately 15.4 mg/g at equilibrium concentration of 1.0 mg/L and pH 6.5. The adsorption results followed intra-particle diffusion model. The removal of arsenate was decreased by presence of phosphate and silicate, while the effects of other cations and anions on the arsenic removal were negligible. Due to its good removal capacity, this method was prerogated by the authors for drinking water treatment.
Again, arsenic removal on nano-sized zero-valent iron supported activated carbonwas reported by Zhuet al. [88] and the corresponding adsorption capacities of arsenite and arsenate, calculated by Langmuir adsorption isotherms, were found as 18.2 and 12.0 mg/g, respectively. The authors investigated the effect of other ions on arsenic removal and found that the presence of phosphate and silicate decreased the removal of both arsenite and arsenate, while the effect of other anions and humic acid was insignificant. Adsorption of As was found to be increased by Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions but Fe2+ ions decreased this process. The removal of As(III) from drinkingwater was found to bemost affected by ions such as, CO3, C2O4, SO4, PO4, and SiO4 at pH 3.0. As (V)
removal was found to be more affected by these metal ions at pH 6.5 and 6.9, respectively.
Mostafa et al. [89] described adsorption strategy of As (V) onto nano-sized iron oxide coated quartz (IOCQ) and reported 100% arsenic (1000 μg/L) removalwithin 5.0min. The adsorption data followed Langmuir isothermmodel and according to the authors, the reported method was quite suitable and the adsorbent is effective for the removal of arsenate from drinking water.
Chowdhury et al. [90] carried out arsenic abatement from aqueous solutions on magnetite maghemite nano-particles and 96–99% arsenic uptake under controlled pH conditions was reported. At pH 2.0, the maximum arsenic sorption was 3.69 and 3.71 mg/g for arsenic (III) and arsenic (V), respectively, with 1.5 mg/L of initial concentration. The authors also examined and described the limitation of arsenic uptake in the presence of a competing anion phosphate. A reciprocal relation was observed with decrease in Arsenic uptake on increasing phosphate concentration. According to the authors, 60% arsenic uptake was achieved in natural groundwater containing N5.0 mg/L phosphate and 1.13 mg/L of arsenic.
As (III) and As (V) species removal on nano-sized amorphous and crystalline TiO2 was described by Jegadeesan et al. [91]. Amorphous and crystalline nano-particles were prepared by the authors with former as an effective arsenic removal adsorbent at 4.0–9.0 pH range. The adsorption isotherms indicated TiO2 sorption capacity was dependent on its site density, surface area, as well as crystalline structure. It was observed that the adsorbent surface remained almost constant for particles between 5 and 20 nm, but As (V) surface coverage increased with the increase in degree of crystallinity, which had been further confirmed by X-ray absorption spectroscopic analysis. The adsorption data indicated the formation of bi-nuclear bi-dentate inner sphere complexes of As (III) and As (V) on amorphous TiO2 at neutral pH that makes it an efficient adsorbent.
The potential of Fe3O4, Mn3O4, andMnFe2O4 nano-phases for the removal of arsenic (III) and (V) from aqueous solutions using the batch technique was investigated and described by Parsons et al. [92]. The Fe3O4, Mn3O4, and MnFe2O4 had the crystal structure of magnetite, hausmannite, and Jacobsite,with the grain sizes of 28, 25, and 12nm, respectively. It was found that the adsorption of either As (III) or As (V) was pH independent from pH 2.0 to 6.0 when 100 ppb of solution was used. However, at pH below 3.0 the nano-materials released high
concentrations of iron and manganese ions into the solution. The amount of both As (III) and As (V) per gram of adsorbent was found to increase with increasing concentration of arsenic in solution. Fe3O4, Mn3O4, and MnFe2O4 nano-adsorbents exhibited binding capacities (μg/g) of 32.2, 8.9, and 718 for As (III) whereas, 1575, 212 and 2125 for As (V), respectively.
Chen et al. [93] described the adsorption of As(V) on Multiwalled boron nitride nano-tubes (BNNTs) functionalizedwith Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) at neutral pH (6.9) and room temperature (25 °C) through batch technique. The equilibrium data supported all isotherms models viz. Langmuir, Freundlich, and Dubinin-Radushkevich, indicating that the mechanism for As (V) adsorption was a combination of chemical complexation and physical electrostatic attraction. Further it was perceived that chemical complexation shows a slight preference for chemi-sorption andphysical electrostatic attractionwith a slight preference for chemi-sorption. The experimental data followed pseudo-second-order kinetics model with the adsorption capacity of 32.2 mg/g as estimated by Langmuir isotherm model.
An et al. [94] prepared carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) or water-soluble starch stabilized Fe\\Mn binary oxide nano-particles for abatement of As (III) and As (V) from water and for immobilization of As (III) in soil. They reported that the adsorbent preferred arsenite over arsenate at pH N 5.0, but the opposite is true at pH b 4.0. The maximum Langmuir capacity was determined as 338 and 272 mg/g for As (III) and As (V) at pH 5.5, respectively, compared to 372 mg/g and 182 mg/g at pH 3.0. Also sorption of As (III) was found less sensitive to pH than that of As (V) and high As (III) sorption capacity was observed over broad pH range of 5.0–9.0.
Shan et al. [95] prepared magnetic nano-particles modified with amorphous Fe and Mn-oxides (Mag-Fe-Mn) via heterogeneous nucleation technique. The particles so obtained were found to have average size the range of 20–50 nm. They employed those particles into the removal of As (III) through batch experiments at 25 °C and the obtained result showed that the maximum sorption capacity of the adsorbent was 47.76 mg/g at pH 7.0. The adsorption isotherm was well defined by Langmuir and Sips equilibrium isotherm models. The kinetics of the adsorption process was well explained by pseudo-second-order.
Similarly, Luther et al. [96] described the removal of either arsenic (III) or (V) from aqueous solution on Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 nano-adsorbents. The binding between adsorbate and adsorbent was found to follow the Langmuir isotherm. The corresponding capacities (mg/kg) of 1250 (Fe2O3) and 8196 (Fe3O4) for As (III) as well as 20,000 (Fe2O3) and 5680 (Fe3O4) for As (III), at 1 and 24 h of contact time, respectively, was reported. The As (V) capacities were determined to be 4600 (Fe2O3), 6711 (Fe3O4), 4904 (Fe2O3), and 4780 (Fe3O4) mg/kg for nano-materials at contact times of 1 h and 24 h, respectively.
A super-paramagnetic ultrafine magnesium ferrite (Mg0.27Fe2.50O4) nano-adsorbent was fabricated by doping Mg2+ into ultrafine α-Fe2O3 nano-crystallite during the hydrothermal process by Tang et al. [97] for the sorption of As (III) and As (V). Its adsorption capacities on As (III) and As (V) were determined to be 127.4 mg/g and 83.2 mg/g, respectively at neutral pH. The workers explained the adsorption mechanism of arsenic via formation of an inner-sphere complex during the removal process.
Adsorption of arsenic onto Fe3O4 nano-particles functionalized via carboxyl (succinic acid), amine (ethylenediamine) and thiol (2,3- dimercaptosuccinic acid) was studied by Singh et al. [98] and result revealed that the optimal adsorption of As3+ was achieved at pH 8.0 with removal percent of 91%, 95% and 97% by carboxyl, amine and thiol MNP, respectively.
Singh et al. [99] synthesized and investigated the applicability of single-phaseα-MnO2 nano-rods and δ-MnO2 nano-fibres for mitigation of As (V) and the sorption result showed that the adsorption equilibrium was better explained by the Langmuir isotherm in the case of α-MnO2 and by both the Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms in the case of δMnO2. Also, it was observed that the adsorption of As (V) onto α-
MnO2 achieved equilibriummore rapidlywith higher adsorption capacity compared to δ-MnO2 making it more efficient one.
Tu et al. [100] described the adsorption of Arsenate on Fe3O4 nanoparticles at 27 °C and at pH 3.0, 7.0 and 11.0 with adsorption capacities of 14.35, 10.12 and4.88mg/g respectively. Table 5 gives a comparison of adsorption capacities of various nano-adsorbents for As (III) and As (V) removal fromaqueous solutions and this table clearly depicts that nanoadsorbents have a greater adsorption capacity [101–116].
1.6.1.2. Cadmium (Cd). Cadmium, a toxic heavy metal, is relatively a less abundant metallic element and one of the non-essential substance released in the environment through a number of anthropogenic activities including the manufacturing of batteries, pigments, and screens, combustion of fossil fuels, metal production, electroplating, alloying, textile operations, acid mine drainage, tanneries and zinc smelting, application of phosphate fertilizers, etc. According toWHO, cadmium is reportedly a potent carcinogen and teratogen infectingmany visceral organs such as lungs, liver, kidneys and reproductive organs [117–120]. According to WHO guideline, the maximum cadmium concentration in water for consumption is 0.003 mg/L [121]. Due to the prevalent cadmium contamination and the low drinking water guideline, there is considerable interest in the development of techniques to remove cadmium from contaminated water. It has been reported previously that cadmium (Cd) ions have little tendency to hydrolyze at pH 6–8 but at pH N11, all cadmium ions exist as the hydroxo-complex in the water.
Feng et al. [122] synthesized magnetic hydroxyapatite nano-particles (MNHAP) to investigate its applicability as an adsorbing material for abatement of Cd2+ and Zn2+ ions from aqueous solutions. The influence of various parameters that affect adsorption process such as contact time, initial metal ion concentration, pH, adsorbent dosage and competitive adsorption on the adsorption process was evaluated. The sorption kinetic data was found to be well explained via pseudo-second order kinetic model with high correlation coefficient (R2= 0.9999) and the adsorption data was found to be well agreed to Langmuir isotherm model. Themaximum sorption capacity of Cd2+ and Zn2+ was approximated as 1.964 and 2.151 mmol/g, respectively with optimum adsorbent dosage of 0.1 g/L. It was found that in the binary component system containing Cd2+ and Zn2+ ions, the adsorption maximum of total adsorption was almost constant, but the MNHAP adsorbents had offered better affinity for Cd (II) ions than for Zn (II) ions, the reason of which was attributed to the greater Langmuir constant of Cd2+ ions than that of Zn2+ ions in the adsorption process. In the desorption experiment, the most efficient eluent used for desorption of metal ions was found to be EDTA with 66.2% and 67% of Cd2+ and Zn2+ ions released, respectively. It was proposed by the authors that themost prominent advantage of the preparedMNHAP adsorbents with paramagnetic behaviour and high specific surface area (142.5m2/g) was the ease of separation from aqueous solutions after the completion of adsorption process.
Gupta et al. [123] prepared a novel adsorbent by modifying orangepeel, an agricultural waste into a magnetic adsorbing material (MNPOPP) by co-precipitating it together with Fe3O4. The cadmium adsorption onto MNP–OPP, magnetic Fe3O4 nano-particles (MNP) and orange-peel powder (OPP) was examined under different experimental conditions, such as pH, ionic strength of solution, natural organicmatter, adsorbate concentration, contact time of reaction between adsorbate and absorbent and temperature conditions. The experimental results revealed a faster kinetics and proved the synthesized adsorbent viz., MNP–OPP as efficient in comparison to those of MNP and OPP. Further, it was confirmed that a complexation and ion exchange mechanism is operative in metal binding process. The adsorption equilibrium data obeyed Langmuir isothermmodel and its adsorption plot showedmaximum Cd2+ removal of 76.92 mg/g at optimal conditions by MNP–OPP. Thermodynamic studies revealed the feasibility of the sorption process. Pseudo-second-order model was proposed as the best fit model with correlation coefficient (R2) above 0.99. Along with batch experiments,
