column studies have also been performed and the results of column studies with a breakthrough capacity of 55.38 mg/g as well as 82% Cd2+ ions removals from an electroplating effluent simulatedwastewater revealed the practicality of the prepared adsorbent. Desorption and reusability studies suggested that after five consecutive adsorption-desorption cycles, the desorption of 98.19–98.66%was achieved with only 4.74% decrease in adsorption efficiency that displayed its good reusability. The authors claimed that the synthesized MNP–OPP could be a propitious and advanced adsorbent in environmental remediation, possessing high adsorption efficiency, faster kinetics supplemented with some additional benefits like ease of synthesis, easy recovery, absence of secondary pollutants, cost-effectiveness, environmentalfriendliness, etc.
Investigation on the abatement of Cd2+ ions from mixed maghemite-magnetite of average surface area 49.5 m2/g and particle size of 20–80 nm as an adsorbent was done by Chowdhury et al. [124]. The results showed that 0.8 g/L ofmaghemite-magnetite particles removedup to 1.5mg/L of Cd2+ ions from the aqueous solution. The adsorption rate of Cd(II) ions was fast initially, and about 40% of total Cd(II) ionswas removedwithin 5min. Thereafter, the adsorption capacity increased slowly with contact time before reaching a plateau after the contact time of 2 h, and then remained constant. Generally, the adsorption capacity of Cd(II) ions by mixed maghemite-magnetite increased with an increase in the pH of the adsorbate solution. With an increase in initial Cd(II) ion concentration, the adsorption capacity of Cd(II) ions on mixed maghemite-magnetite increased but the removal percentage of Cd(II) ions decreased. An increase in adsorbent dosage increased Cd(II) removal but decreased adsorption capacity. Adsorption of Cd(II) ions by mixed maghemite-magnetite was found to follow the pseudo-second-order kinetics model with correlation coefficient value (R2) being above 0.99. The adsorption equilibrium data were fitted well by Langmuir isotherm model with regression coefficient (R2) value of 0.9931 indicating a monolayer adsorption on a uniform surface with a finite number of adsorption sites. Intra-particle diffusion studies suggested that adsorption of cadmium is partly diffusion controlled and partly due to an electrostatic effect along with specific adsorption involving the adsorption of Cd2+ and CdOH+ onmixedmaghemite-magnetite nanoparticles in the alkaline pH range.
Lu et al. [125] developed a new solid phase extraction (SPE) adsorbent i.e., silica gel modified by a Carboxy-methyl chitosan (CMCS) grafted with β-cyclodextrin (CMCS-g-CD) for removal of Cd2+ ions. The optimum conditions for batch experiments i.e., pH, adsorbent dosage and contact time as well as column experiments i.e., concentration and volumeof elution solutionwere optimized, respectively. The kinetic modelling showed that the data was best explained via pseudo-secondorder kinetics with R2 N 0.999 and agreement between calculated Qe value (10.6 mg/g) and the experimental Qe (exp) value (11.3 mg/g) was reported. It was also found that the presence of co-existing ions had no remarkable effect on the separation and determination of the test ion. The sorbent regeneration studies revealed that the column remains relatively stable up to at least 20 extraction–elution cycles without any obvious decrease of recoveries. The authors proposed that this method can be applicable to the determination of trace Cd (II) ions in a variety ofwater sampleswith a lowmethoddetection limit, high accuracy (% recovery ranging from96.0 to 102.0) andhighprecision (%R.S.D. ranging from 0.2 to 0.6).
Srivastava et al. [38] synthesized nano zinc oxide (n-ZnO) particles via sol-gel method and investigated its applicability in removal from aqueous solutions. The prepared nanoparticles were of 17–50 nm in size as shown in Fig. 3. A high removal of Cd (II) ions i.e., 92% from its aqueous solutions with initial metal concentration of 200 mg/L by nZnO particles was achieved within 1 h of contact time that supported its requisition in treatment of effluents containing Cd (II) ions.
1.6.1.3. Chromium (Cr). Chromium is one of the most extensively used element and thus quotidian drinking water contaminant finding
applications in various industrial processes, such as in leather tanning, paints, dye industries, cement industries, steel fabrication, photographic industries, wood preservatives, and metal finishing, etc. Such a largescale utilization of Cr lead to chromium based pollution in the environment. However, its toxicity and mobility are strongly dependent upon its oxidation state. Chromiumpredominantly exists in nature in two oxidation states viz., Cr (III) and Cr (VI). Among these two species, Cr (III) is an essential trace element and is known to participate in a number of reactions including metabolism of glucose in human beings. Cr (III) is less toxic at low concentrations and is regarded as a nutrient for humans. However, it shows toxicity at higher concentrations and its long-term exposure leads to a number of health complications including allergic reactions and sometimes cancer. As compared to Cr (III) in terms of toxicity, Cr (VI) is relatively a more toxic and soluble specie. It is known to pose a serious threat to the environment and human being. It can cause bronchitis, dermatitis, perforations in nasal septum and can have carcinogenic and mutagenic effects. Its maximum allowable limit in drinking water is defined as 50 ppb total chromium by World Health Organization (WHO) [126–132].
Silica modified with imidazole and chloride as counter ion (SilprImCl) has been investigated by Wang et al. [133]. The maximum adsorption capacity of Cr (VI) was 47.79 mg/g, achieved at pH 2.0 when initial Cr (VI) concentration was 150 mg/L. The adsorption isotherm was supported by Langmuir model with correlation coefficient (R2) value of 0.9976 instead of Freundlich model having R2 value of 0.9594. The kinetics of the adsorption process follows the pseudo-second-order with the values of the rate constant, the equilibrium adsorption capacity, the initial adsorption rate and the correlation coefficients being 0.0461 gm/g/min, 41.841 mg/g, 80.654 mg/g/min and 1, respectively. The experimental findings exhibited that the modification of silica with imidazole significantly enhance its adsorption capacity for Cr (VI) than the unmodified one. The authors conducted adsorption–desorption experiments of the SilprIm-Cl and found that the adsorbent could be regenerated with the maximum desorption percentage (99.3%) and reused for eight times at least by simple washings with NaCl and water.
Recillas et al. [134] prepared CeO2 nano-particles which crystallizes in a cubic fluorite structure with size of 12 nm and surface area 65m2/g. Through the experimental result it was found that the removal efficiency decreases from 96.5%–50.6% after 4 h of adsorption. Themaximum sorption capacities of Cr (VI) onto per gram of CeO2 nano-particles was obtained after 24 h as 1.88 mg, 83.33 mg and 121.95 mg, at the initial concentration of Cr(VI) of 0.6, 37.5, 80 mg/L respectively. The experimental data supported well the Freundlich adsorption isotherm model with the correlation coefficient value (R2) of 0.9554 and its corresponding n and k values being 2.1 and 20.57 respectively. The kinetics of the adsorption process followed pseudo-second-order that
assumed that the rate limiting step is the chemical sorption involving valence forces through sharing or the exchange of electrons between the CeO2 nano-particles behaving as an adsorbent and Cr (VI) solution as an adsorbate.
Albadarin et al. [135] synthesized hydrous cerium oxide nano-particles denoted as HCO via the precipitation approach for the abatement of Cr (VI) from aqueous solutions. The experiments were conducted according to the factorial experimental design and the optimum conditions for the best abatement results so obtained were 1.923 mmol/g of Cr (VI) metal concentration, pH 2.0, temperature 20 °C and a sorbent dose of 4 g/dm3 after 96 h of contact time. A significant decline in Cr (VI) adsorption occurred when the pH was higher than 2, the reason of which was attributed to the electrostatic repulsion occurring between the Cr (VI) ions and surface of the HCO nano-particles. The ionic strength independence of Cr (VI) ions adsorption shows that the adsorption mechanism does not involve ion-exchange process. Langmuir and Redlich-Peterson isotherms were found the best-fitting isotherms for the experimental results with the value of Qmax. equal to 0.828 mmol/g.
Badruddoza et al. [136] investigated the efficacy of phosphonium silane coated magnetic nano-particles (PPhSi-MNPs) synthesized via a simple one-step co-precipitation process toward the abatement of Cr (VI) ions in mixture of As (V) ions. The BET specific surface area and average particle size of these NPs were estimated as 105.7 m2/g and 10.2 nm respectively. The adsorption equilibrium data for both the ions was well supported by the Langmuir isotherm model. The optimum adsorption capacities for As (V) and Cr (VI) ions were reported as 50.5 mg/g and 35.2 mg/g respectively. The evaluation of kinetic data showed that the kinetics of the process followed pseudo-secondorder. The authors explained that the sorption mechanism involves a synergic electrostatic interaction as well as ion-exchange between positive ligands and negative pollutant anions that plays a significant role in enablinghigh adsorption of bothmetal ions. PPhSi-MNPs nano-particles so synthesized were easily magnetically separated, regenerated and then reused for two to three consecutive adsorption-desorption cycles without any appreciable loss of its original adsorption capacity enabling it an efficient adsorbent.
Organo-montmorillonite supported iron nano-particles were incorporated for carrying out reduction of Cr (VI) ions by Wu et al. [137]. The experimental results revealed thatwith a dose at 0.47 g/L, a total removal of 106 mg Cr/g Fe0 was obtained. The sorption capacities of both supported and unsupported iron nano-particles toward reduction of Cr (VI) ionswere compared and result of comparison indicated that reduction of Cr (VI) wasmuch greater with organo-montmorillonite supported iron nano-particles. Kinetics of the removal process followed pseudo-second order model.
Selective adsorption of Cr (VI) ions in the presence of other coexisting ions such as Cu2+, Zn2+, Ni2+, Cl− and NO3− from aqueous solution was carried out by Bhaumik et al. [138] onto Polypyrrolepolyaniline (PPy-PANI) nano-fibres. The adsorbent was prepared without template via coupling of propagating PPy•+ and PANI•+ free radicals by simultaneous polymerization of Py andANImonomers in presence of FeCl3 oxidant. The result of sorption experiment shows that optimum adsorption capacity of the PPy-PANI nano-fibres for Cr (VI) ions was 227 mg/g. The adsorption of Cr (VI) on the nano-fibres surface was highly pH dependent and the optimum pH for the maximum removal of Cr (VI) by PPy-PANI nano-fibres was found to be pH 2.0. The adsorption kinetics was described by the pseudo-second-order model, and Langmuir isotherm model was well supported by the adsorption isotherm data. The evaluation of thermodynamic parameters for the adsorption system suggested that the adsorption process is spontaneous, endothermic (capacity increased with increasing temperature) and marked with an increase in entropy at the solid–liquid interface. The mechanism behind the removal of Cr (VI) by the PPy-PANI nano-fibres was a combined effect of anion-exchange and reduction of Cr (VI) to Cr (III) ions. Competitive effects of other co-existing ions on Cr (VI)
removal were found insignificant, affirming selective adsorption of Cr (VI) ions. Regeneration and reusability of the PPy-PANI nano-fibres were tested for four successive adsorption–desorption cycles in which it was found that there is no appreciable loss of original capacity in the first two cycles. These results confirm that the material could be considered as an alternative adsorbent for the removal of Cr (VI) from aqueous solution.
Luther et al. [139] carried out the sorption experiment for the removal of Cr (III) or Cr (VI) ions onto Fe3O4 and MnFe2O4 nano-particles under light and dark conditions. These particles were synthesized via precipitation method and their corresponding size was determined to be 22.4 ± 0.9 nm (Fe3O4) and 15.5 ± 0.5 nm (MnFe2O4). The pH of the solution played a significant role in the binding of chromium (III) and chromium (VI) ions where optimum binding of Cr (III) and Cr (VI)was observed at pH 6 and pH 3.0 respectively. Adsorption isotherm studies were performed under light and dark conditions at 23 °C in order to determine the removal capacity of the synthesized nano-particles and the results of the experiment had been tabulated in Table 6. An insight into the binding capacity of these nano-particles showed that the binding of chromium (III) and chromium (VI) to the Fe3O4 and MnFe2O4 nano-materials have opposite behaviour with greater binding to Fe3O4 in comparison toMnFe2O4 nano-particles, under both the conditions. The reason behind this difference in the binding capacity under light and dark conditions may be explained by the surface chemistry and the interaction of lightwith the surface of thematerial and the chromium ions. The binding of metal ions to nano-materials is affected by the surface charge of the nano-material which could be affected by the presence or absence of light. The increase in capacity noticed under thedark reaction conditionmaybe a synergistic effect of surface charges and the absence of light during the experimentation. The influence of pH on the binding capacity also showed the opposite behaviour as it was noticed that Cr (VI) displayed greater binding to both nano-materials at low pH and decreased to zero binding above pH 6.0, whereas, Cr(III) bound to a very lowextent at pH2.0 and increased to amaximum around pH 6.0. The isotherm studies depicted that the binding of both these ions followed the Langmuir isotherm model. In order to understand themechanismof binding, the data obtained through the thermodynamic studies has been taken into account that suggested that probably, the reaction has two different mechanisms for the binding of chromium (VI) possibly through physi-sorption and through some
type of exchange mechanism. However, chromium (III) binds to the nano-materials through an exchangemechanismas the entropy of reaction was found to increase under all reaction conditions.
A 100% removal of Cr (VI) ions from aqueous solution onto iron nano-particles of 15 nm prepared via a simple sol-gel method was reported by Sharma et al. [140]. Various experimental parameters such as initial metal ion concentration, contact time, adsorbent dosage, pH and temperature on the removal of chromium were evaluated and authors found that the removal of chromium increased from 88.5% to 99.05% when its initial concentration was decreased from 15 to 5 mg/L at optimum conditions. The adsorption was found to be highly pH dependent and the maximum removal was obtained at pH 2.0. The removal process was found to the kinetics of both, pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order models with the values of R2 being 0.997 and 1.0 respectively. Intra-particle diffusion studies reflected its influence on the removal process. The thermodynamic results obtained through experimentation supported the fact of increased adsorption on increasing temperature and revealed that removal processwas feasible, spontaneous and endothermic in nature.
Srivastava et al. [141] synthesized a heterogeneous adsorbent (HA) and investigated its applicability in the sorption of Cr (VI) ions from aqueous solutions. The authors observed that metal uptake decreased with decreasing initial metal ion concentrations andmaximum removal for each concentration range has been achieved within 60 min. The kinetic modelling showed that the equilibrium data fitted well to pseudo-second-order equation having correlation coefficient value (R2) = 0.998 and qe = 1.672. Langmuir isothermmodel best described the adsorption process with R2 value being 0.999, among various adsorption isotherm models considered by the authors. The sorption process of hexavalent chromium onto the heterogeneous adsorbent was found to be endothermic in nature.
1.6.1.4. Copper (Cu). Copper is awell-known element having importance in a number of reactions occurring inside humans as an important constituent of various enzymes. It is considered as an essential element for human being and required in a certain defined limit above which it adversely affects the normal cellular functioning. It is a quotidian element and present in municipal wastewaters. Copper finds a number of applications such as supplement in cattle feed, as a constituent of fertilizers and pesticides, in manufacturing of copper wires, water pipes and brass radiators, in fireworks and antifouling paints applied on ship hulls [142]. Excessive intake of copper results in Indian childhood cirrhosis [143] Alzheimer's disease, Tyrolean infantile cirrhosis [144], Wilson disease [145], familial amyotrophic lateral scelerosis (FALS) [146]. It is also reported that enzymes, whose activities depend on sulphahydryl and amino groups [147] get strongly inhibited by Cu2+ ions which have high affinity for N and S−containing donor ligands [148]. WHO recommends a minimum value of 2 mg/L in drinking water [149] but various industries are releasing higher amounts of Cu(II) into water streams. Therefore, it becomes necessary to explore new that can effectively remove these Cu2+ ions from the wastewaters before their discharge into water resources.
There are innumerable numbers of techniques that have been applied so far for abatement of Cu2+ ions fromwastewater such as precipitation, flocculation, membrane filtration, reverse osmosis, ion exchange, nano-filtration, cementation, bio-sorption, electro-coagulation and adsorption [150–158].
Kumar et al. [159] carried out experiments for removal of a mixture ofmetal ions in aqueous solutions viz. Cu (II), Zn (II) and Ni (II) ions. For this purpose, they prepared silica (SiO2) nano-particles functionalized with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), synthesized by using (3-aminopropyl) tri-ethoxyl-silane (APTES) as a bridging link between silanol groups (SiOH) of silica and carboxylic group of EDTA. There is observed a slight decrease in specific surface areas of as received silica, APTES modified silica and EDTA silica and this decrease in the specific surface areas is attributed to the functionalization of silica. This
modification of silica i.e. grafting by EDTAwas done by a simplemethod to enhance the adsorption capacity of silica for Cu (II), Zn (II) and Ni (II) ions from aqueous solution. The monolayer adsorption capacity for Cu (II), Zn (II) and Ni (II) ions was estimated as 79.36, 74.07 and 67.56mg/g, respectively. The influence of various parameters on the removal of metal ions was investigated and found that removal increased with the increase in solution pH, contact time and concentration. The equilibrium timewas found to be 45min for all the threemetal ions. Kinetic studies suggested that the sorption of Cu (II), Zn (II) and Ni (II) ions onto EDTA–silica followed the pseudo-second order kinetics with slight involvement of film diffusion and intra-particle diffusion mechanisms. Langmuir isothermmodel was well supported by the adsorption data. Thermodynamic results reveal that the removal of metals onto EDTA–silica was endothermic and spontaneous in nature. The adsorption of these heavy metals onto EDTA–silica was found much higher than the silica gel and APTES–silica and followed the order: Cu (II) N Ni (II) N Zn (II). It was observed that over 80% of removal onto EDTA–silica was achieved within 30 min of the commencement of processwhere initial adsorption seemed to be fast due to complexation between themetal ions and vacant sites of EDTA. Afterwards, the uptake of metal ionsdecreased gradually and attained equilibrium. Themaximum adsorption of Cu (II) and Zn (II) was observed at pH 5.5 whereas, Ni (II) ions showsmaximum removal at pH6. Therewasmarked an increase in removal of Cu (II), Zn (II) and Ni (II) by EDTA–silica with the increase in solution temperature from 30 to 50 °C. This removal order of metal ions onto EDTA–silica can be explained on the basis of complex formation between metal ions and EDTA. For the EDTA-metal complex, log K value of Cu (II), Ni (II)) and Zn (II) are 118.8, 18.6 and 16.5, respectively and thus favouring the higher removal of Cu(II) ions among the considered ions. These results suggested that EDTA–silica could be a potential material for the removal of these test heavy metal ions form aqueous solutions.
Karabelli et al. [160] prepared a nano-composite of iron nano-particles and alumina (Al–n-ZVI) for sorption of Cu (II) ions from aqueous solutions. This adsorbent was synthesized by introducing alumina into a solution of Fe2+ ions, which was further reduced to metallic iron by using boro-hydride ions. The characterization results showed that iron nano-particles present in dispersed form on the surface of alumina, while another part exists in its distinct chain-like structure that resembles that of pure n-ZVI. The surface of Al–n-ZVI composite was seen to be heterogeneous as shown in Fig. 4. The synthesized sorbent exhibited fast uptake of Cu (II) ions, and its fixation capacity was estimated as 1.50 mmol/g (95.3 mg/g), which is well above that of pure alumina (0.32 mmol/g; 20.3 mg/g). The experimental findings indicated that almost a complete removal of Cu2+ ions can be achieved using Al–n-ZVI at the initial concentrations of 10 and 50mg/Lwith only a small amount of the applied adsorbent dose (0.050 g for 50 mL solution). This result
was reported as a significant one, using least amount of adsorbent used. The sorption capacity at 500 mg/L initial Cu2+ concentration of Al–n-ZVI was about 1.50 mmol/g or 95.3 mg/g, which is approximately five-folds that of pure alumina (0.32 mmol/g; 20.3 mg/g).
Chitosan-coatedmagnetic nano-particles (CCMNPs)modifiedwith a biodegradable and eco-friendly biologic reagent,α-ketoglutaric acid (αKA) was synthesized by Zhou et al. [161] and utilized for removal of toxic Cu2+ ions from aqueous solution. TEM images showed that the particles are highly dispersed with size of 30 nm without any aggregation. The maximum adsorption capacity (qmax) for Cu2+ ions was estimated to be 96.15 mg/g, which was slightly higher than that of pure CCMNPs. The adsorption equilibrium studies suggested that Cu2+ adsorption supported Langmuir model. The sorption reaches equilibrium within 60 min and 50% of Cu2+ ions being adsorbed within 2 min from the commencement of theprocess. The desorption studies showed that no significant desorption hysteresis has been noticed. In addition, the high stability and recovery capacity of the synthesized nano-particles i.e., (α-KA-CCMNPs) ensured that these novel magnetic nano-particles have potential applications as adsorbents for removing Cu2+ from wastewater.
1.6.1.5. Lead (Pb). After the most poisonous metal Arsenic, the second position is occupied by Lead (Pb) in the list of leading 20 hazardous heavy metals as reported by the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) [162]. Lead is known to instigate a multitude of dysfunctions including physiological, biochemical, as well as behavioural; particularly in children [163]. Thismetal is supposed to be extremely toxic leading to mental retardation, encephalopathy, convulsions and anaemia [164– 166]. The prime sources of Pb(II) toxicity includes storage batteries, formulation of paints and pigments, oil, fertilizers, ammunition, solder, plumbing fixtures, ceramics, glass, cable coverings, radioactivity shields, lead smelting andmining are some of the important industrial activities that contribute toward lead concentration into the aqueous medium [167–169]. According to US Environmental Protection Agency guidelines, the maximum contamination level for Pb2+ in drinking water is 0.015 mg/L [170]. It is therefore mandatory to bring reduction in the lead levels in drinking water, wastewater and water used for normal usage to the maximum permissible concentration. Various physicchemical and biological methods have been developed for removing lead from contaminated waters, however it is best accomplished by adsorption on suitable adsorbents [169,171].
A novel nano-material, cellulose modified nano-scale manganese oxide composite (C–NMOC) has been synthesized by Maliyekkal et al. [172] and tested for its applicability for Pb(II) ions removal from aqueous solutions. The experimental results revealed that the synthesized material with 4% Mn loading gives optimum removal capacity of 80.1 mg/g. The result so obtained was compared by carrying out similar experiments onto n-MnO2 (NMO) prepared via similar route. The pH of the solution played a vital role in adsorption as C-NMOC showed enhanced binding capacity than (NMO) at lower pH values (pH b 4). The process of adsorption onto both NMO and C-NMOC was very fast and attained pseudo equilibrium at 60min from commencement of the process. It was observed that most of adsorption occurred within 10 min, the reason of which may be attributed to greater density of reactive sites on surface of particles, large surface area, and/or higher reactivity of the surface sites. The adsorption isotherm was better explained by Sips isotherm model. Kinetic study indicated that the reaction order was pseudo-first-order with physi-sorption playing a dominant role. Regeneration study of the adsorbent has been carried out and it was concluded that at the end of third successive adsorption-desorption cycle, reduction of only 10% in adsorption efficiency was reported. Thus, making it a good candidate for efficient removal of Pb(II) ions with repeated use.
Venkateshamet al. [173] demonstrated the sorption of Pb(II) ions on nano-sized ZnOnanoparticles prepared via gel combustionmethod. The
average particle size and BET specific surface area of the synthesized zinc oxide was estimated as 40 nm and 80.425 m2/g respectively. The influence of pH, metal ion concentration and adsorbent dose on the adsorption process was examined and it was found that adsorption of Pb was maximum for the lower concentration of Pb solution, acidic solution (pH=4.0) and becomes constant in basic solution and also adsorption shows an increment with increase in the adsorbent dosage i.e. maximum at 1.0 g. The correlation coefficient (R2) values obtained from Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherm viz., 0.9987 and 0.9999 respectively, were almost the same. Therefore, both the adsorption isotherms perfectly fitted to Pb (II) adsorption on nano-ZnO particles.
Xu et al. [174] synthesized a novel adsorbent iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles and Ca-alginate immobilized Phanerochaete chrysosporium for removal of Pb(II) ions from water. The maximum bio-sorption efficiency of Pb (II) was 96.03% achieved at pH 5.0 and 35 °C. The initial uptake of metal was very fast and equilibrium was achieved after 8 h of process. The optimum bio-sorption capacity reached up to 185.25 mg/g dry bio-sorbent at a 500 mg/L Pb(II)-containing solution. According to Pearson correlation analysis, bio-sorption efficiency was mostly controlled by contact time of process and pH of the solution, but initial Pb(II) concentration also had a great effect on it, while the temperature and bio-sorbent dosage affected the sorption efficiency to a lower extent. Kinetics of the adsorption process was well fitted by pseudo-second-order kinetic models, in contrast to the findings of Maliyekkal et al. [172] which showed higher correlation coefficients in the range of 0.9970–0.9985. The adsorption isotherm was described well by the Langmuir model having R2 value of (0.9870– 0.9895). The presumption that adsorption took place in two stages, viz., a very rapid surface adsorption and slow intra-particle diffusion was verified by intra-particle diffusion model fitting. Further, discussions on the adsorption mechanism with respect to the FTIR analysis of the adsorbent inferred that the adsorption might be attributed to two possible mechanisms, i.e., combination with bio-sorption affinity of the fungus and the enhanced intra-cellular accumulation by iron oxide nano-particles. Possibly, the immobilization of P. chrysosporium with iron oxide nano-particles and Ca-alginate endowed the adsorbents with higher adsorption capacities and good reusability, by the introduction of FeAO groups and enhanced interior accumulation. Even after five cycles of adsorption–desorption, the adsorption ability was regained completely and the adsorption efficiency of Pb(II) ions was maintained above 90%. The desorption and reusability results indicated that the adsorbents were stable with good reusability.
An amino-functionalized magnetic nano-adsorbent (MNPs-NH2) was prepared via hydrothermal method by Tan et al. [175] for abatement of Pb(II) ions from aqueous solution. The adsorption equilibrium reached within 1 min of the process. The pseudo-second order was proved to be the best kinetic model for explaining the adsorption kinetics that indicated the adsorption was chemi-sorption. The adsorption isotherm was supported by Langmuir isotherm model. Moreover, this nano-adsorbent efficiently removed about 98% of Pb (II) from industrial wastewater and tap water and desorption efficiency higher than 99% can be achieved. Furthermore, regeneration and reusability study indicated that the MNPs-NH2 can be reused for at least 15 times in successive adsorption processes without any significant loss in the adsorption performance which could be reported as the highest among various regeneration experiments conducted so far. Therefore, authors suggested that the amino-functionalized magnetic nano-adsorbents could be regarded as a potential and stable candidate for efficient and renewable adsorbent for Pb (II) ions.
Nassar [176] utilized Fe3O4 nano-particles of size 22±1.5 nm for the removal of Pb (II) ions from aqueous solutions and found that adsorption was fast, and equilibrium was achieved within 30 min. It was observed that the amount of Pb (II) ions adsorbed increases with increase in temperature, suggesting an endothermic adsorption process. The optimal pH value for Pb (II) adsorption was around 5.5.
Furthermore, the addition of co-existing cations such as Ca2+, Ni2+, Co2+, and Cd2+ showed no remarkable influence on Pb (II) removal efficiency. The adsorption equilibriumdata fitted accurately to both Langmuir aswell as Freundlich adsorption isothermmodelswith correlation coefficients (R2) value of 0.99. The thermodynamic study revealed that of Pb (II) adsorption onto the Fe3O4 nano-adsorbents was spontaneous, endothermic and physical in nature. The desorption and regeneration studies have proved that Fe3O4 nano-adsorbents can be employed repeatedly for a number of timeswithout hampering its adsorption capacity. Therefore, Fe3O4 nano-adsorbents are recommended as fast, effective and inexpensive adsorbents for rapid removal and recovery of metal ions from wastewater effluents.
Hydrous manganese oxide (HMO) was prepared by Xu et al. [177] via reduction of KMnO4 by H2O2 using the cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template having BET specific surface area of 79.31 m2/g. The adsorption equilibrium was well supported by the Langmuir isotherm equation with qmax value of 352.55 mg/g at 298 K and high correlation coefficient value; R2 = 0.997. The adsorption behaviour of adsorbent was investigated and found to follow pseudo-second order kinetics with correlation coefficient values (R2) over 0.996. The influence of ionic strength on Pb (II) ions adsorption onto HMO was examined at pH 4.0 and result showed that with increasing the ionic strength from 0.01 to 0.20 mol/L of NaNO3, only a negligible decrease of Pb (II) uptake by HMO was detected. These results indicated that the adsorption of Pb(II) on HMO was ionic strength independent. The adsorption mechanism of Pb (II) ions onto the adsorbent involves inner-sphere complexation rather than ion-exchange which was confirmed by its ionic strength independence. The value of adsorption activation energy, Ea for Pb (II) adsorption onto the HMOwas estimated as 38.23 kJ/mol, which suggested that adsorption was chemi-sorption in nature for the adsorption of Pb (II) onto the surface of HMO. The uptake of Pb (II) on the surface of HMOwas explained by correlating it with increase in surface hydroxyl group content and the main adsorbed speciation was PbOH+. The final chemical state of Pb (II) on the surface of HMO after the completion of process was similar to PbO. The authors suggested thatHMOmust be a promisingmaterial to be used for removal of Pb (II) ions from aqueous solutions.
1.6.1.6. Mercury (Hg). Among the list of toxic and hazardous heavy metals known to cause toxicity to the environment as well as human beings, mercury is one of the most toxic one exhibiting its effects even at low dosages because of its bio accumulative tendency [178]. The major contamination sources of Hg in the environment include waste discharge from chlorine, burning of fossil fuels, volcanic action, paper and pulp, oil refinery and paint manufacturing industries, plastic and battery manufacturing industries as well as improperly disposed, thermometers, barometers, pumps, and lamps [179]. The upper safe limit for mercury is 0.001 ppm beforemetal toxicity occurs, which is the lowest among all heavymetal ions [180]. The toxicity of Hg depends strongly on its oxidation state; themost toxic form of Hg is the Hg2+, which is highly reactive and binds to the amino acid cysteine in cases of mercury poisoning [181]. Mercury enters our food chain through bacterial formation of methyl mercury in lower level sediments which are taken in by fish. Mercury exposure to human adults and children even at low dosage can affect their various organs. Absorption of mercury and its compounds occurs through the gastrointestinal tract, skin as well as through the lungs in humans which is then further stored in the visceral organs such as brain, liver, kidneys, spleen and bones, leading to carcinogenic, mutagenic, and teratogenic effects. Moreover, a number of other health complications associated with the Hg-poisoning has been reported including paralysis, tyrosinaemia, serious intestinal and urinary disorders, dysfunction of the central nervous system, intoxication and inmore severe cases leads to death [182]. Numerous treatment methods have been employed for removal ofmercury from aqueous solutions, includingprecipitation [183], coagulation [184],membrane separation, [185], ion exchange [186] and adsorption [187–191] among
which adsorption process is most commonly adopted because it is fast, simple to operate and cost effective and also exhibit efficient removal capacity.
Sheela et al. [192] carried out experiments on the removal of Hg (II) ions from aqueous solution containing Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions as well by using ZnO nano-particles synthesized via a simple precipitation method. The particles having average size of 26 nm exhibited the maximum adsorption capacities of 357, 387 and 714mg/g for Zn (II), Cd (II) andHg (II) ions respectively. Among various adsorption isotherms models, Langmuir model proved to be the best fit to the experimental data for all the three ions under consideration. Effects of various parameters on the adsorption experiment was also evaluated and the results revealed that the sorption of Zn (II), Cd (II) andHg (II) ionswasdependent on the pH, metal ion concentration, contact time and temperature. The authors found that adsorption capacity shows increment with increase in initialmetal ion concentrationwithin defined range at lower temperatures and at an optimum pH value of 5.5. The explanation of sorption mechanism was given by the workers as at pH 5.5 there was observed an increased dissociation of surface hydroxyl groups from the surface of ZnO nano-particles leading to the subsequent formation of metal ions species such as CdOH2, Cd(OH)2, ZnOH+, Zn(OH)2, HgOH+ and Hg(OH)2 of low solubility that led to themaximum percentage removal ofmetal ions. Kinetic studies showed that themechanism for adsorption of metal ions followed the pseudo-second-order ratemodel, which provided the best fit for the experimental data. The adsorption rate (h) calculated from pseudo-second-order rate equation for Zn (II), Cd(II) and Hg(II) ions was 6.79, 23.92 and 45.09 mg/g min respectively, indicating the higher adsorption rate of Hg(II) compared to Cd(II) and Zn(II) ions onto ZnO nano-particles. Intra-particle diffusion model was explored using Weber-Morris model for understanding of sorption mechanism which suggested that the initial adsorption was controlled by the film diffusion, which was further followed by the pore diffusion. The thermodynamic studies suggested that the adsorption process was spontaneous and exothermic for all the ions under study onto ZnO nanoparticles.
Similarly, TiO2 nano-crystals have been employed as an adsorbent by Ghasemi et al. [193] for abatement of Hg (II) ions from aqueous solutions. The synthesis involves the hydrolysis of TiCl4 at room temperature and results showed that the 13.2% of particles consisted of anatase and 86.8% rutile phase with average grain size of 8.8 nm and 10.2 nm respectively. These nano-crystals having specific surface area of 98.743m2/g showed N96% percentage removal of Hg (II) ions. The influence of various parameters viz., initial metal concentration, pH, temperature and contact time of adsorption process were investigated and results of experiment revealed that adsorption process attained equilibrium at 420min with optimum adsorption at pH= 8.0. It was explored by the authors that the solution pH strongly affected the removal process. Freundlich isotherm with correlation coefficient value being R2 = 0.995, was found to be best fitted to the experimental data, which fits well to multilayer adsorptions on heterogeneous surfaces. The kinetics studies of adsorption showed the involvement of pseudosecond-order with k2 = 2.8126 × 10−3 g/mg/min, at 303 K. From the values of the thermodynamic parameters, it was concluded that the adsorption process was spontaneous and endothermic in nature contrary to the thermodynamic findings of the Sheela et al. [192].
Further, functionalization of silica with thiol coated onto magnetic nano-particles (TF-SCMNPs) has been carried out by Hakami et al. [194] using co-condensation pathway. The optimum adsorption for Hg (II) onto TF-SCMNPs of 50 nm was found to be 207.7 mg/g when 4 mg/L of TF SCMNPs were used. Adsorption isotherm was well explained via both the Freundlich and Langmuir isothermmodels. The adsorption of Hg (II) ions was found constant at 10 °C and 22.5 °C, but decreased when temperature increased to 35 °C. The effect of pH was found to be highly initial concentration of Hg (II) dependent. The authors reported that the adsorption remains unaffected by the presence of co-existing anions and light cations under the conditions tested.
1.6.1.7. Nickel (Ni). Nickel is heavily utilized in industries mainly due to its anti-corrosion properties and hence may find its way into water resources from discharges through various industrial activities including steel manufacturing, mining operations, electro-plating techniques, ceramics, pigments formulation, battery, etc. [195–196]. This extensive utilization of Ni-containing materials and its consequent by-products sometimes leads to environmental pollution by Ni [197]. Long term exposure to highly Ni-polluted environments has the potential to produce a variety of pathological effects in humans varying from contact dermatitis to lung fibrosis, cardio-vascular and kidney diseases, and sometimes even cancer [197–198], gastro-intestinal complications (e.g. nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea) and pulmonary fibrosis [199]. Since Ni is always present in environment and its exposure in low amounts cannot be avoided andmaynot beharmful to humans, consequent health problems associatedwith Ni-pollution arise due to exposure to high doses of Ni present in near or in Ni processing areas [197]. TheUS Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) recommends maximum allowable limit of nickel in drinking water should not exceed 0.07 mg/L [200]. To meet these stringent standards, it inevitably requiremany utilities to upgrade its present system or consider new treatment options [201]. The most often used techniques for Ni removal from water include precipitation, ion-flotation, ion-exchange, membrane filtration, adsorption and several electro- chemical treatment techniques including electro-coagulation, floatation, dialysis, deionization and deposition [202].
Srivastava et al. [203] synthesized nano-Alumina via sol-gel method and investigated its applicability in mitigation of Ni (II) ions from aqueous solutions. The synthesized nano-particles of size 15–20 nm have surface area estimated as 78.79 m2/g, as shown in Fig. 5. It was found out through experimentation that sorption of Ni (II) ions is dependent upon initial Ni (II) solution and increased from (96.60 to 99.0) % by decrease in concentration from (75 to 25) mg/L at 25 °C at an equilibrium time of 120min. The agitation speed was found to have sound effect on the removal of Ni (II) ions and optimum removal achieved at 100 rpm. The kinetic data of the adsorption experiment well supported the pseudo-second order with correlation coefficient value (R2) of 0.999. In examining adsorption isotherm, various isotherm models viz., Langmuir, Freundlich, Dubinin-Radushkevich, and Temkin were considered and interestingly it was found that the equilibrium data fittedwell to almost all the isotherm models considered during experimentation with one particular model suitable at some temperature while other model at some other temperature. The activation energy of the sorption process was calculated as 8.96 Kj/mol indicating the physi-sorption nature of adsorption. The values of the coefficient ofmass transfer for the systems were evaluated and found significant that indicates the feasibility of a sufficiently rapid transfer of adsorbate species from the bulk to the surface and/or solid/liquid interface. The authors claimed that the nano-
alumina is quite efficient candidate for removal of Ni (II) ions from aqueous solution and it can be used for designing treatment plants for the removal of Ni(II) from water and wastewater.
1.6.1.8. Selenium (Se). Among various elements that have been enlisted as an essential element so far, Selenium (Se) is also such a naturally occurring element in the environment known for having nutritive value for humans. Like any other element, selenium also possesses certain defined limit for its concentration in environment making it essential or hazardous for living beings. It has been reported that its concentration in environment is increasing continuously through a number of industrial practices viz., mining operations, thermal power plants, burning of fossil fuels, etc., and also via anthropogenic activities including drainage systems and agricultural-irrigation practices, etc. [204–206]. Selenium is known to have a very narrow limit defined for its deficiency and toxicity based on its chemical form and concentration in the environment [207–209]. It has been reported by various workers that have worked on it that Se usually exists as two oxo-anionic species in aqueous solutions i.e., selenite (SeO32−, Se4+, Se (IV)) and selenate (SeO42−, Se6+, Se(VI)), having toxic and bio-accumulative properties. Due to its bio-accumulation it poses a great threat to the health of water-dwelling animals (i.e., fish, water-fowl, etc.), birds and mammals including humans [210,211]. The health complications associated with high level of Se in the environment include tissue damage, reproductive failure, teratogenic (disturbances to the development of an embryo) effects, and even elimination of fish communities [206].
Several treatment methodologies for the removal of Se from aqueous environment have been devised including anion-exchange, reverse osmosis,micro-algal–bacterial treatment, and phyto-remediation [212– 213]. Adsorptionmethod involving adsorbents, such as, pure and coated montmorillonite, aluminium oxides, aluminium-basedwater treatment residuals, zerovalent iron, various forms of iron oxy-hydroxides (α-,β,γ-, and δ-FeOOH), ferrihydrite, magnetite, and hematite [214–219] have been employed in removal of Se from water resources.
Gonzalez et al. [220] synthesized (MnFe2O4) as a nano-Jacobsite phase material with an average particle size of 27.5 nm for the removal of both selenite and selenate from aqueous solutions in pH range of 2.0 to 6.0. The maximum removal of both selenite and selenate achieved within 5 min of contact time with the synthesized material at pH 4.0. The equilibrium data supported Langmuir isotherm with sorption capacities of 6573.76 and 769.23 mg Se kg−1 of nano-adsorbent for selenite and selenate, respectively having their corresponding correlation coefficient values of 0.9990 and 0.9976 respectively. The effect of interfering anions such as Cl−, NO3−, SO42−, and PO43− having concentrations from 0.1–100 ppmon the binding of Se onto nano-Jacobsitewas also investigated and found that introduction of Cl− and NO3− had no significant effect on the ability of the adsorbent in removal of both selenium oxo-anions from solutions. Furthermore, the additions of SO43− ions found to have a competitive effect only on the removal of selenate at 10 ppm and more pronounced at 100 ppm of SO42− ion concentration, and PO43− at concentrations of 100 ppm decreased the removal of selenate to 87% while selenite removal decreased to 20% respectively.
Similarly, studies on the sorption of Se (VI) ions onto nanomaghemite particles have been carried out both atmacroscopic andmicroscopic levels by Jordan et al. [221]. The maximum removal was achieved at lowpH i.e. in acidic condition and decreasedwith increasing pH as well as ionic strength of the solution. The mechanism behind the removal through the adsorption was explained on the basis of electrophoretic mobility measurement that suggested the formation of outersphere complex during the sorption of Se (VI) onto nano-maghemite as shown in Fig. 6. Further, studies at microscopic level propounded that sorption of selenium (VI) onto maghemite involves the formation of bi-dentate outer-sphere surface complexes over the whole pH range under study i.e., 3.5–8.0. In other words, the selenate oxy-anions are sorbed onto the maghemite surface primarily via electrostatic
interaction with the nano-particles having a small contribution approx. 15% of an inner-sphere complex in a bi-nuclear corner-sharing geometry.
Hydrated γ-Al2O3 having average particle size of 13 nm was employed by Elzinga et al. [222] for studying its interaction with selenate, selenite, and chromate ions in aqueous solutions. The pH of the solution was found to have pronounced effect on the extent of adsorption indicating increase in adsorption of these oxy-anions under test with decreasing pH. It was also observed that chromate ions and selenate ions adsorption was ionic strength dependent in the pH range of 4.0– 9.0, whereas selenite adsorption was found independent of ionic strength. The adsorption of chromate ions from aqueous solutions showed its adsorption peak at pH 5.0, whereas, no such peaks were observed for selenate and selenite ions. The results of experiments revealed the different modes of adsorption of the species at the surface of hydrated γ-Al2O3 nano-particles, where selenate adsorbed as nonprotonated outer-sphere complexes, chromate indicated the formation of a mixture of mono-protonated and non-protonated outer-sphere adsorption complexes, whereas, selenite formed an inner-sphere surface complexe in a bridging configuration.
Jordan et al. [223] investigated the removal of Se (VI) ions onto TiO2 nano-particles grown as anatase phasewith average grain size between 5 and 10 nm. In order to explain the adsorption mechanism of Se (VI) ions onto anatase nano-particles, the experimental data was analysed via a number of techniques. The results of batch experiments revealed the dependence of the Se (VI) sorption on the pH and ionic strength of the solution. It was anticipated by the authors that only sorption processes were responsible for the partitioning of selenium (VI) ions between the aqueous phase and the surface of anatase nano-particles which was further evidenced by zero reduction of selenium (VI) ions at both homogenous and heterogeneous levels during HG-AAS and XPS measurements. It was observed that isoelectric point of anatase upon selenium (VI) sorption remain unchanged at the time of electrophoretic mobility measurements, which strongly suggested the formation of outer-sphere complexes on its surface which was further confirmed by ATR FT-IR results. On the basis of ATR FT-IR spectroscopic findings, the authors concluded that over the whole pH range of observation i.e., 3.5–11.0, selenium (VI) was sorbed onto anatase via formation of outer-sphere surface complexes, or, in other words the selenate oxy-anions were sorbed onto the anatase surface primarily via electrostatic interaction as discussed earlier [221].

sections.heading: 2. Zero-valent iron nano-particles (n-ZVI)
sections.text:
Nanoscale zero valent iron (n-ZVI) particles, with their diameter ranging from 10 to 100 nm and reduction potential (E°) of −4.4 V, are proposed to be first among the nano-scale environmental technology
commercially available for water treatment. In comparison to the granular iron, n-ZVI particles have surface areas up to 30 times greater than powder of granular iron, thus promises to be significantlymore effective than granular iron. In the context of performance, the reaction rates are reported to be 25–30 times faster and the sorption capacity is alsomuch higher as compared to that of granular iron. The reason behind such a fascinating property is attributed to their large reactive surface area of approximately142.0 m2/g with particles of size 2–5 nm [224].
Likewise, other nano-particles, zero valent iron (n-ZVI) nano-particles can also be synthesized via both the strategies of nano-particle synthesis i.e. top-down and bottom-up approaches. For example, synthesis of n-ZVI particles have been reported, via reduction of goethite and hematite particles with hydrogen gas at elevated temperatures (e.g., 200– 600 °C) [225], fabricated from vacuum sputtering, via decomposition of iron penta-carbonyl (Fe(CO)5) compounds in organic solvents or in an inert atmosphere i.e., argon [226–229] and by electro-deposition of various ferrous salts. Among variousmethods of synthesis, reduction of ferric (Fe(III)) or ferrous (Fe(II)) salts with sodium borohydride (NaBH4) has been widely carried out by many researchers [230] due to its relative simplicity, incorporation of only two very common reagents without requirement of any special instrument, etc.
4Fe3þ þ 3BH4− þ 9H2O→4Fe0↓þ 3H2BO3− þ 12Hþ þ 6H2↑ Fig. 7, shows TEM micrographs of n-ZVI particles synthesized using sodium boro-hydride method [231] and it has been found that the nano zero valent iron particles assumed a typical core-shell structure with core consisting mainly of metallic or iron (zero valent) and shell of Fe (II) and Fe (III) oxides, formed as a consequence of oxidation of the metallic iron as shown in Fig. 8. n-ZVI particles are fairly reactive in water and hence act as an excellent electron-donor that makes it a versatile remediation material [232], along with advantages of being relatively inexpensive, non-toxic and high energy effectiveness [233]. Several adsorption studies have been performed for mitigation of inorganic pollutants on n-ZVI, some of which has been discussed herein.
Fu et al. [234] synthesized resin supported nanoscale zero-valent iron (R-n-ZVI) via the borohydride reaction and reported 84.4% removal of Cr(VI) onto it. Through batch experimentation authors evaluated various factors viz., resin dose, n-ZVI dose, initial metal ion concentration and pH, that affects the metal ion removal and results revealed that at pH 5.0, optimum Cr (VI) ions removal was achieved when the initial concentration of Cr (VI) was 20.0 mg/L at an adsorbent dose of 41.3 mg/g and resin concentration of 20.0 g/L. SEM studies evidenced that n-ZVI particles in R-n-ZVI became spherical in shape after reacting with Cr (VI) ions. This phenomenon was attributed to the co-precipitation of Cr (III) and Fe (III) ions onto the surface of resin which was confirmed by X-ray diffraction patterns that Fe0 particles get diminished after the reaction. It was also found that the adsorbent can be efficient
to remove Cr (III) also, by ion exchange process at pH6.3 and by theprocess of precipitation at pH above 6.3, whereas the removal mechanism of Cr (VI) ions involves chemical reduction. Cr (VI) ions removal was found to be increased with higher n-ZVI particles loads and resin amounts and decreased as initial metal ion concentration and pH of solution increased.
Similarly, Petala et al. [235] reported 100% Cr (VI) removal onto MCM-41-supported nano-scale zero-valent iron (n-ZVI) synthesized by impregnating the mesoporous silica matrix with ferric chloride, followed by chemical reduction with NaHB4 at pH 3.0 and 6 mg/L of Cr (VI) concentration. The results also indicated a high pH-dependent reduction efficiency of the material, whereas kinetics was well explained by a pseudo-first-order kinetic model.
For the abatement of aqueous Cd (II), Cr (IV), and Pb (II) ions through the means of magnetic separation, Huang et al. [236] investigated the application of n-ZVI particles synthesized via both electrosprayed (E-n-ZVI) and non-electro-sprayed (NE-n-ZVI) methods with different concentration levels (0.186–1.86 mg/mL). The influence of the reaction time (5–20 min.) and magnetic treatment time (1– 30 min.) on the magnetic removal efficiencies of metal ions were studied and the results exhibited that with the use of 1.5 mg/mL E-n-ZVI or NE-n-ZVI removal efficiencies of N80% for Pb (II), Cd (II), and Cr (IV) ions have been achieved. Approximately, 20% increase in Pb (II) removal efficiencywas observedwhen themagnetic treatment timewas increased from 1 to 20 min, with no significant changes on the removal of Cd(II) and Cr(IV) ions. Whereas, increasing the reaction time decreased the Pb(II) removal efficiency, with no marked changes for Cd (II) and Cr(IV) ions. Finally, it was proposed by the authors that 1 min reaction and 5minmagnetic treatmentwere the optimum conditions to achieve considerable heavy metal removals.

sections.heading: 2.1. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs)
sections.text:
After the first discovery of CNTs in 1991 [237] they have gained considerable research attention in various scientific areas. CNTs, due to their tunable physical, chemical, electrical, and structural properties are widely used as sorbents, filters, catalysts, and membranes in water treatment processes.
The structure of CNT principally consists of a tubular sheet of graphite with its building blocks consisting of honeycomb lattices of carbon atoms [238]. These nano-particles can be synthesized by a number of techniques including arc discharge, catalytic growth, laser ablation or CVD [239]. Several functional groups such as hydroxyl (\\OH), carbonyl
(\\C_O) and carboxyl (\\COOH), etc., can be introduced onto the CNT layermaking itmore hydrophilic and suitable for removingpolar pollutants in contaminated water. As a result of Vander Waal's attractive forces, CNT develops aggregated pores with large mesoporous volume that contributes to its superior adsorption performance for any types of pollutant [240]. On the basis of hybridization of carbon atoms and the range of diameter, CNTs are classified into two types viz., Singlewalled CNTs (SWCNTs) and Multi-walled CNTs (MWCNTs) as shown in Fig. 9. SWCNT is a single layer of graphene sheet rolled up into hollow cylindrical shapes of diameters ranging from 0.3 to 3 nm [241], while the MWCNT consists of at least two concentric layers of graphene with diameters up to 100 nm [242–243]. As SWCNT consists of carbon atoms, arranged into hexagonal lattices [219], it is more difficult to be purified and possess more aggregation tendency than MWCNT. Although MWCNT has a higher purity than SWCNT [244], the latter is more costly than the former.
Adsorption studies on CNThave been started several years later than its first report in 1991 [245] and gained momentum in the past decade. CNTs strongly adsorb many pollutants due to the diverse pollutant-CNT interactions involving п-п interactions, covalent bonding, hydrophobic effects, and electrostatic interactions [246].
As a result of surface functionalization, CNTs gets oxidized and possess high adsorption capacities for metal ions with fast kinetics. The functional groups attached on the surface of CNTs became the sites of adsorption of metal ions mainly through the electrostatic interaction and formation of chemical bondswithmetal ions. Several sorption studies have been performed onto CNTs and results showed that the adsorption capacities of these nano-particles are far better than a number of other conventional water treatment sorbents; some of the results of which are discussed here.
Sankararamakrishnan et al. [247] reported the maximum sorption capacities of Cr (VI) and Cd (II) ions as 264.5 and 229.9mg/g respectively onto Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) grown over Fe- and Ni-doped activated alumina (AA) by chemical vapour deposition (CVD). To produce nanofloral clusters (NCs) these were then washed with hydrochloric acid. The experimental results showed that the equilibrium reached at 1.5 h for Cr (VI) and at 2 h for Cd (II) at pH 2.0 and 7.5, respectively. The equilibrium data was best described by the Langmuir isotherm model. Table 7 shows the comparison of adsorption studies of CNT or modified CNTs used earlier, as adsorbents for Cr (VI) and Cd (II) ions removal with the synthesized nano-materials [248–256]. The high adsorption capacity was attributed to the presence of activated alumina, CNT, amorphous carbon and various functional groups attached to the surface such as carboxyl, carbonyl andhydroxyl, etc., present in the clusters of the nano-sorbent. (See Table 8.)
The sorption of Cd2+ ions onto Manganese dioxide (MnO2) coated on acid oxidized multi-walled carbon nano-tubes (MnO2/o-MWCNTs) was studied by Luo et al. [255] and results showed a maximum
adsorption capacity of 41.1 mg/g at pH 5.0. The adsorption process was found to be a complex process including mechanisms of both physi- and chemi-sorptions. The equilibrium data suited well to Langmuir isotherm model and the adsorption process followed pseudo-second-order kinetics. The overall process of adsorption of Cd (II) ions appeared to be influencedby externalmass transfer, intra-particle diffusion, and chemical adsorption mechanisms.
Venkata Ramana et al. [256] synthesized silver nanoparticles deposited multiwalled carbon nanotubes (Ag-MWCNTs) via chemical reduction method for removal of Cu(II) and Cd(II) ions from aqueous solutions. The experimental findings showed that the maximum sorption of Cu (II) ions achieved was 99.54% and that of Cd (II) was 98.36% at pH 6.0 and 7.0, respectively. The kinetics of the adsorption process followed pseudo-second-order and equilibrium isotherm was excellently explained by Langmuir isotherm model. It has been further observed that the overall adsorption process was controlled via chemical processes either by sharing or by exchange of electrons between the adsorbate and the adsorbent in the solution.
Similarly, 97.3% removal of Pb (II) ions from aqueous solutions at pH 9.0 onto MnO2 coated multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs/ MnO2) was reported by Abdel Salam [257]. The equilibrium reached within 5 min of the reaction time and the sorption process was found to bewell described by pseudo-second-order with R2 N 0.99 and Elovich model with R2 N 0.92 at all temperatures defined for the experimentation. The process of adsorption was found to be complex having a number of different steps but mainly controlled by liquid-film diffusion mechanism.

sections.heading: 2.2. Miscellaneous metal ions
sections.text: In the above section, we have discussed the adsorption of certain heavy metals regarded as pollutants above certain permissible limits defined for them on a number of nano-adsorbents synthesized so far. In addition to these heavy metals, there are certain other metals that are known to exert detrimental effects on the lives of flora and fauna and interfere with their normal functioning in due course of time. In this section, we have enlisted such metallic species and provided an insight into the work carried out by various workers for their mitigation from aqueous solutions in context of water remediation.

sections.heading: 2.3. Antimony (Sb)
sections.text:
Antimony, naturally occurs in the environment either in the form of sulphide ore stibnite (Sb2S3) or valentinite (Sb2O3). It is widely used in paint industries, rubber compounding and in semiconductor devices as well. Evidences supporting health complications associatedwith the exposure of antimony over a certain limit are available which shows that the abdominal pain, headache, mouth ulcers, loss of appetite, etc. are the normal symptoms. Chronic exposure leads to lung, heart and gastrointestinal diseases [258]. Therefore, it is essential to remove antimony from water resources.
Xi et al. [259] studied the adsorption of Sb (III) onto Goethite nanoparticles synthesized via precipitation method and investigated the impact of certain competitive anions on the removal of Sb (III) ions. The sorption process was carried out at three different temperatures (283, 298 and 318 K) and found out to follow pseudo-second-order kinetics and the equilibrium isotherm was modelled using Langmuir and Freundlich models. Freundlich model with correlation coefficient value of (r2 N 0.975) showed a better fit in comparison to Langmuir model (r2 N 0.932). Themaximum adsorption capacity, Q0 was estimated as 19,370.40 μg/L, at 298 K. The studies on the influence of competitive ions on the adsorption of Sb(III) ions on goethite reflected that the adsorption kinetics remain unaffected by the presence of NO3− and SO43− ions whereas the presence of PO43− showed a marked decrease in the value of rate constant. It appeared through the experimental result that the adsorption kinetics of phosphate on goethite followed the
same trend as that of Sb(III) ions. On the basis of earlier explanations, data suggested that the sorption of phosphate took place in at least two different processes viz., a very fast process and a very slow process, and it was found that the sorption of Sb (III) was heavily inhibited by PO43− ions initially. It was proved earlier by researchers that the surface of goethite nano-particles include three different types of hydroxyl groups and the authors proposed that Sb (III) and PO43− ions might have reacted with the same type of hydroxyl groups. It was also found that the oxidation of Sb (III) to Sb (V) occurred which was further accompanied by the adsorption process. The thermodynamic results indicated that the adsorption process was spontaneous and exothermic in nature.

sections.heading: 2.4. Palladium (Pd) and Platinum (Pt)
sections.text:
Palladium and Platinum are white, lustrous silver-metals having wide applications in catalytic converters in automobiles, low voltage electrical contacts, as a catalyst in hydrogenation and de-hydrogenation reactions, in jewellery making, watch and balance bearings, mirrors of scientific instruments, and in many electrical appliances viz., wide screen televisions, computer systems and mobile phones, etc. Although they are regarded as of low toxicity, Pd is found to may cause skin, eye, respiratory tract irritation along with skin sensation. All compounds of Pd are found to be highly toxic and carcinogenic in nature. Palladium chloride, if swallowed and absorbed by laboratory animals, leads to bone marrow, liver, and kidney damage of animals. While, the health impacts of platinum are found to be strongly dependent upon the kind of bonds involved, exposure level, and immunity of the person that is exposed. Platinum salts are known to have several health effects, such as, DNA alterations, allergic reactions of skin and mucous membrane, deafness, damage to organs such as liver, kidney, and bone marrow, etc. The most serious concern about palladium is that it can cause enhancement of the toxicities of other toxic chemicals such as selenium (Se) in the human body. Thus, these metals should not be released to the environment without proper treatment [260].
Zhou et al. [261] studied the abatement of Pt(IV) and Pd(II) ions on ethylenediamine modified magnetic chitosan nanoparticles (EMCN) having 15–40 nm of average particle diameter. It was found through the experimentation that the loading capacity (qm) of the adsorbent wasmaximum for Pt (VI) ionswith the value of 171mg/g in comparison to the Pd (II) ions having sorption capacity of 138 mg/g at 298 K. This value was found to be higher than that of unmodified chitosan and reason behind this was explained as the modification of chitosan with ethylenediamine introduces amine groups on its surface that upon interaction with Pt (VI) and Pd (II) ions resulted in enhanced sorption capacity. The adsorption equilibrium isotherm was explained via Langmuir model. The difference in the affinity of the EMCN nanoparticles toward Pt (VI) and Pd (II) ions was ascribed to the formation of chloro-anionic species i.e., platinum forms chloro-platinum species at pH 2.0 that diminished the number of chloride ions available for the formation of palladium chloro-anionic species, which further resulted into decreased adsorption of Pd(II) ions. This mechanismwell explained the fact underlying the decreased sorption of Pd (II) ions in the presence of Pt(VI) ions and confirmed the sorption preference of the EMCN for Pt(VI) over Pd(II) ions. The stability and regeneration of the EMCN particles was also investigated and found out that its sorption capacity, even after 5 cycles of adsorption-desorption maintained over 90% level. Thus, the authors proposed that EMCN particles, with their large
surface area, high surface reactivity, selective adsorption and ease of separation properties could be a potential candidate for the sorption and potential regeneration of Pt (VI) and Pd (II) ions from the aqueous solutions.

sections.heading: 2.5. Uranium (U) and Thorium (Th)
sections.text:
Uranium (U) and Thorium (Th) are the radioactivemetals, found extensive applications in various fields. Uranium is widely used in practical uses of nuclear energy, as a shielding to protect tanks, in bullets and missiles, and in high amounts in phosphate fertilizers. The health effects include kidney diseases when taken up in large amounts. Long time exposure to uranium nuclides formed during radioactive decay may lead to development of cancer. Thorium and its compounds found important applications in gas mantles, toothpaste, dating hominid fossils, as a nuclear fuel, in the production of refractory materials for metallurgical industries, in formation of high temperature crucibles, etc. Exposure to thorium leads to several lung diseases, pulmonary and pancreatic carcinoma,mutations in geneticmaterial. Itmay develop liver diseaseswhen injected with thorium for special X-rays. Due to its storage capability in bones, it may cause bone cancer in due course of time. Thus, disposal of suchmetals must be in accordancewith the federal, state, and local regulations [262].
Nilchi et al. [263] synthesized tin oxide nano-particles (n-SnO2) via precipitationmethod and employed it as an adsorbent to investigate the removal of Uranium (VI) ions and Thorium (IV) ions from aqueous solutions. The maximum removal capacity was obtained as 66.67 mg/g and 62.50mg/g for U (VI) and Th (IV) ions respectively at pH6.0. The impact of pH on the adsorption of these test ions was also investigated and it was found that the amount of adsorption of these ions on the surface of nano tin oxide increases with increase in pH of the solution. The mechanism of removal involved in the removal process was explained as the surface of SnO2 nanoparticles has isoelectric point at pH 7.0 that meant it bear positive and negative charges above and below pH N 7.0 respectively. At lower pH, less sorption of uranium ions has been observed which was ascribed to the electrostatic repulsion between the the positively charged uranyl ions and protonated active sites on the adsorbent. Depending upon the pH of the solution, uranium exists as (UO2)2(OH)22+ species up to pH 5.0 and (UO2)3(OH)5+ species at pH value higher than 5.0. Similarly, thorium exists as Th(OH2)2+ species in the acidic condition and as Th2(OH)26+ ions at higher pH. The optimum adsorption of uranium and thorium ions was observed at pH 6.0. The adsorption isotherm was found to be well explained by Freundlich
isotherm model with fractional value of 1/n (0 b 1/n b 1) that clearly corresponds to the heterogeneous surface of the adsorbent. The kinetic data of the experiment suggested that the process followed pseudo-second order kinetics with the value of R2 being (0.99 b R2 b 1.00). The thermodynamic data revealed that the adsorption processwas an endothermic and spontaneous in nature.

sections.heading: 2.6. Nanotoxicity-harm to biotic life
sections.text:
The unique feature of shape and size as well as greater surface area to volume ratio of nanoparticles enables them to be used as an excellent adsorbent for removal of contaminants present in aqueous streams also make their easy passage into the living systems. The threat extended to the environment as well as human beings by the particles of nano-dimensions is termed as nanotoxicity. The metal oxide nanoparticles such as alumina, titanium oxide, zinc oxide and carbon nanotubes are reported for their toxicities in living organisms. Themost common passage of nanoparticles into human being is through skin [264], inhalation [265] and ingestion [266]; and after entering into the bloodstream, they can reach to various body parts and affect vital organs of human being such as liver, kidneys, heart, brain and nervous system [267–270]. Their greater chemical reactivity results into generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals whose presence in the body may cause oxidative stress and inflammation leading to consequent damages tomembranes, proteins and DNA [271]. Some nanoparticles weaken the immune system of body by overloading the phagocytes of the body leading to inflammation.
The adherence of non-biodegradable nanoparticles on surface of the body affect regulatory mechanisms of some enzymes and proteins. The mutation in DNA [270], structural damage to mitochondria [268] and cell death [272] are some of the major complications associated with the toxicity of nanoparticles in the human body. Therefore, it is imperative to adopt efficient ways for the management of disposal of used nanoparticles. The best way of disposal management is recycling of the used and exhausted nanoparticles in manufacturing of bricks, stones, cement based materials etc. Apart from this, their disposal may be carried out by filling them in steel cylinders and dumping them deep into the earth.

sections.heading: 2.7. Comparison of adsorption capacity of nanoparticles with conventional low-cost adsorbents
sections.text:
Although nanoparticles have been extensively used as a potential adsorbent for the removal of various metallic species from aqueous solutions, no paper has been reported so far on the commercial applications of nanomaterials in water treatment. The inadequate management of the exhausted nanoparticles, budding stage of regeneration of nanoparticles and toxicities introduced into living beings due to their improper handling and disposal are some of the issues that questions their applicability over conventional low cost adsorbents in water treatment. Further, low-cost adsorbents have been used for the removal of almost all types of pollutants, in contrast to the nanoparticles that have been used in the removal of few contaminants only. Besides, due to varied experimental conditions employed for the removal of same pollutant for both the low-cost adsorbents as well as nanoparticles, exact comparison between these two is not possible. However, attempts have been made to compare the adsorption capacities of both these two types of adsorbents for removal of certain heavy metals. Asuquo et al. [273] reported adsorption of Cd(II) and Pb(II) on commercial activated carbon (CGAC) with maximummonolayer adsorption capacities of 27.3 mg/g and 20.3 mg/g for Cd(II) and Pb(II) ions respectively. The rapid uptake of both the ions occurred within 30 min while 1.964 mmol g−1 of Langmuir capacity for Cd(II) over magnetic hydroxyapatite nano-particles (MNHAP) was reported by Feng et al. [122]. Similarly, Adebisi and Alaba [274] investigated sorption of Pb2+ and Zn2+ ions on activated carbon prepared from palm oil mill effluent
(POMEAC) and found adsorption capacity of 94.34 mg/g for Pb(II) ions under optimized experimental conditions which is quite low as compared to the removal result obtained through hydrous manganese oxide (HMO) with qmax. value of 352.55 mg/g [177]. For adsorption of Cr(VI) ions, Kumar and Jana [275] prepared activated carbon from fox nutshell (FNAC) and obtained maximum capacity of 74.95 mg/g at initial concentration of 35 mg/L under specified experimental conditions, whereas, CeO2 nanoparticles exhibited adsorption capacity of 121.95 mg at 80 mg/L of initial Cr(VI) concentration [134]. Similarly, a number of other heavy metal ions removed by activated carbons prepared by different precursors have been reported. On comparing the overall performance of nanoparticles with low cost adsorbents viz., activated carbons toward heavy metal removal, nanoparticles appear to be better adsorbent in terms of their good working capacities, low contact time and faster removal, low dose requirements, ability to function under varied conditions of pH; and removal at microgram level of permissible limits of hazardous metals. Thus, regardless of some drawbacks, nanoparticles can be the good candidate for water treatment by incorporating certain measures such as preparation of nanoparticles with bio-degradable properties in an eco-friendly manner, safe handling and disposal of nanoparticles to avoid environmental hazards; and optimization of the treatment techniques for applications at pilot and commercial levels by using column operations.

sections.heading: 2.8. Economic analysis of treatment of wastewater through nanoparticles
sections.text: The adsorption process utilized for the treatment of metal bearing water and wastewater is arguably one of the most popular method among other available methods by being cost-effective in nature. Activated carbon as an adsorbent is attractive to many scientists because of its effectiveness in the removal of metallic species at trace levels, but its high cost limits its extensive application [276,277]. Therefore, emphasis has been given on the application of low-costmaterials as sorbents such as agricultural wastes, seafood processing wastes, biomass, clay materials, etc. They have proven themselves as an efficient adsorbent due to their cost-effectiveness and capability to removal metal ions even at trace levels from aqueous medium. However, in order to achieve maximum adsorption and enhancement in separation rate, newmaterials as potential adsorbents are imperative. Nano-adsorbents potentially offer a more cost efficient water treatment and remediation technology due to their size, adsorption efficiency and regeneration. Regeneration as well as cost of regeneration of adsorbents in water treatment is one of the crucial aspects in controlling the economy of water treatment technologies and deciding the applicability of adsorbents for commercial use. The economic evaluation of the wastewater treatment by a number of nanoparticles has been carried out by many researchers and the findings concluded that it offers more efficient water treatment technology among other methods and adsorbing materials available [278,279]. Gusain et al., [280] estimated the total cost of adsorbent synthesis including energy consumption as 8.46 INR/g.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
This critical insight into various efforts that have been taken by variousworkers for environmental remediation in terms of removal of variousmetallic species from aqueous solutions shows that introduction of nano-technology into water and waste-water treatment processes proved to be a boon for environmental remediation. Nano-particles, in comparison to other conventional low-cost materials offered a number of advantages such as large surface area to volume ratio, low dose requirement, ease of separation, regeneration and reusability, fast removal, etc. However, their requirement in less amount as well as their regeneration and reuse capability makes their application economical. They are also capable of removing inorganic pollutants even at very low concentrations of metal ion solutions under varied experimental conditions of pH and temperature. On the basis of various results of
adsorption processes discussed herein, it can be concluded that the nano-particles could be a potential, stable and efficient candidate for removal of heavy metals from water and waste-waters.

referenceMentions.context: Adsorption is acknowledged as one of the most suitable water strategies because of its simplicity of operation and the accessibility of an extensive variety of high adsorption limit and large scale sections [4].

fly ash [9–11], chitosan [12–13], kaolinite [14], zeolite [15–16], montmorillonite [17], sphagnummoss peat [18], wollastonite [19], bentonite [20], sawdust [21], seaweeds [22], soya cake [23], redmud [24] and alumina [25–27] have been incorporated by various workers and reported for the removal of metallic pollutants from aqueous solutions and wastewaters.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 29 December 2016 Received in revised form 13 May 2017 Accepted 18 May 2017 Available online 25 May 2017 Wastewater treatment and water purification have always posed challenges to mankind and this problem has become severewith escalating population and industrialization. This topic has attracted the global scientific community. Activated carbon adsorption became popular choice forwater purification but its high cost prompted scientific workers to search for its alternates. In that series, several materials including minerals, waste materials, cellulosic materials, etc. were also applied as adsorbents. Recently, especially after advent of nano technology, there was a shift toward application of nano materials as ‘adsorbents’ and the term was coined as ‘nano adsorbents’. Present reviewhas been focussedon the application of commonnanomaterials for the removal ofmetallic species which are found in aqueous environment. The ‘most common’metallic species are As, Cd, Cr, Cu, Pb, Hg, and Ni. Sb, Pd, Pt, U and Th are the othermiscellaneousmetallic species where nano particles are applied for their removal from aqueous solutions and water. We have critically discussed the articles published recently on this topic. © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
